docs.lead_paragraph: There were, of course, the joyous celebrations, the honking horns, cheering crowds and waving flags, as if war had been won and tyranny ended. But word that Osama bin Laden had at last been killed brought out other voices on Monday as well: sober, reflective, wounded still and vengeful, but also articulate in hope. As Americans streamed to the World Trade Center site and spontaneous gatherings across the New York region, there were countless more subdued scenes that captured the day's emotion: a woman at St. Patrick's Cathedral, praying amid flickering votive candles, her face strangely powerful in its stillness.

headline.main: A Mood of Triumph and Sober Reflection

docs.abstract: Reactions of New Yorkers to the news of Osama bin Laden's death a decade after 9/11 run the gamut from exuberance to somber reflections on vengeance, justice and the possibility of hope; photos (M)

byline.original: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN; Reporting was contributed by James Barron, Joseph Berger, Cara Buckley, Sam Dolnick, Anemona Hartocollis, Javier C. Hernandez, Corey Kilgannon, Colin Moynihan, Andy Newman, Sarah Maslin Nir, Ashley Parker, Liz Robbins, Nate Schweber, Alice Speri, Jason Tomassini, Paul Vitello, Benjamin Weiser, Michael Wilson and Karen Zraick

docs.lead_paragraph: Steve Riedner of Schaumberg, Ill., was a 55-year-old tool-and-die maker, a job that involves difficult mental calculations, and a frequent speaker at community meetings when he found himself increasingly at a loss for words and unable to remember numbers. He even began to have difficulty reading his own written comments. The neurologist he consulted thought Mr. Riedner had suffered a stroke and for three years treated him with cholesterol-lowering medication. But instead of his language ability stabilizing or improving, as should happen following a stroke, it got worse.

headline.main: A Thief That Robs the Brain of Language

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael Dell built his company and his fortune in the personal computer business. But the company’s future is increasingly going to rest on services and the bigger gear used in data centers — server computers, storage and networking equipment.

headline.main: Dell’s Future Beyond the PC Business

docs.abstract: Dell is making a big push beyond its PC business into services and data center technology.The big potential new market is in offering services to midsize businesses.
docs.snippet: Dell is making a big push beyond its PC business into services and data center technology.The big potential new market is in offering services to midsize businesses.
